name: Tewa
period: documentation from older ethnographic sources dated 1916-1968, in Tewa-speaking villages
place: Tewa-speaking Pueblos in New Mexico: San Ildefonso, Isleta, Jemez, Cochiti, Taos, Nambe
culture: The Tewa-speaking Eastern Pueblos are a tribe of the Southwest culture area in N America, in the southern Rocky Mountains along Rio Grande and tributaries. A Pueblo is a village made of multistoried dwellings, as well as its people. The Pueblos farmed (mostly corn, squash, and beans), kept turkeys, hunted and gathered, and developed crafts.
astronomy: The Pueblos had a keen interest in the night sky, judging by the many representations of stars in their artwork. In both Pueblo and nearby Navajo creation mythology, a creation figure intends to place the stars in the sky in groups, but another figure ruins this plan and scatters the stars. For the Eastern Pueblos in particular, a creation story tells that the mythical creation mothers created 'star people' and made their eyes out of sparkling white crystal. These people lived in groups, but when the task was given to a mole to carry them in a sack to the upper world, but the mole disobeyed and let the stars fly out and occupy the sky randomly. Only a few of the stars remained in the sack, and these were placed in groups: the Big Dipper, Orion's belt, and the Pleiades. The characters involved vary among stories, as do the star groups (which sometimes include IAU Del, Venus, and other unidentified groups). It is possible that some of the names are Spanish borrowings. No native names are provided in the source [miller1997stars], but some may be documented in the older ethnographic sources dated 1916-1968.
data summary: 12 constellations are identified with variable (but generally low) certainty (of which 10 with line figures), plus names for Venus, the Milky Way, Pleiades, and Canopus. The data comes from pages 174-180 in the source [miller1997stars]. Sky objects 001-005 plus the Milky Way (as The Endless Trail) form a scene corresponding to an exodus myth.
certainty: The author identifies the stars and constellations based on textual documentation from earlier sources. Many of the star identifications are made to a sky region rather than to star names; all the line figures are then tentative and rarely well motivated. When there are multiple names for the same asterism, these may be collected from different villages. Other constellations are named, but not identified: Big Round Circle (representing a dance performed in October, and expected to be a large, irregular group of stars near IAU CrB), Star House (a big constellation in the Western sky after sunset in September), Sandy Corner (a large group of dim stars near IAU Ori), Horned Star (a bright star), Ladder, The Hand (present in other cultures), Wheel, Bull's Eye, Pot-Rest Stars (possibly Orion's belt).

constellations.certainty: The line figure is drawn in the source (except for the shorter lines between close or small stars) but the shape is not justified. It is a naturalistic human shape with a sash, as the character is named.
constellations.description: The Pueblo myth of Long Sash parallels the biblical story of Moses leading the Israelites out of Egypt. Long Sash was a warrior entrusted by the tribe with the task of leading them to a new land where they could live in peace away from destructive neighbouring tribes. The long journey followed The Endless Trail (the Milky Way), and important points in the journey were marked by The Place of Decision (002), The Place of Doubt (003), and The Three Stars of Helpfulness (004).

constellations.certainty: The line figure is drawn in the source, and the two stars are identified.
constellations.description: A step of the journey led by Long Sash (001) where the tribe took the decision to continue. It is said that even today, people look at these stars when making important decisions.

constellations.certainty: The line figure is drawn in the source and matches Rey's naturalistic crab. However, the reason for this shape of the line figure is not explained in the source, so is probably a default to a Western figure.
constellations.description: A step of the journey led by Long Sash (001) where Long Sash was doubtful and unsure which way to go; he asked for (and received) guidance from the above.

constellations.certainty: The line figure is drawn in the source and is located in IAU Leo, but the stars are only tentatively identified; they are the brightest in Leo, and they match the shape drawn. The shape represents a travois: an A-shaped frame structure that was used to drag loads over land.
constellations.description: Towards the end of the journey led by Long Sash (001), the tribesmen became kinder to one another; some men made a travois (an A-shaped frame structure that was used to drag loads over land) to carry their own, as well as an old woman's belongings.

constellations.certainty: Given the group (7 animals) semantic, this is not a line figure.
constellations.description: In the story of Long Sash (001), seven animals (represented by the Big Dipper) each gave Long Sash and his tribe a sign about where they should settle.

constellations.certainty: The line figure is not drawn in the source. Since the tail is said to refer to the handle only, it must be attached to the animal, so this represents the animal by closing the rectangle of the dipper.
constellations.description: The tail refers to the handle of the Big Dipper.

constellations.certainty: Identified as Orion's belt in the source, but not drawn, so the lining is uncertain. The row semantic motivates the line of three.
Identified as Orion's belt in the source, but is not drawn, so the lining is uncertain. The group semantic motivates the lack of lines.
Identified as the bowl of the Little Dipper in the source, but not drawn, so the lining is uncertain. The yoke semantic motivates the shallow U shape.
Identified as IAU Del in the source, but not drawn, so the lining is uncertain. The slingshot semantic does match the standard IAU Del P-shape, so this is used.
Identified as IAU CrB in the source, but not drawn, so the number of stars used is uncertain. The bowl semantic does make the shape (an open curve) certain.
constellations.description: Women would place a bowl (fired to a black colour) near a fire so that the meal in it would dry.

constellations.certainty: Not identified in the original source from 1916; suggested to be part of the Western asterism of the Northern Cross, based on its presence in the Pawnee culture, also as a Bird's Foot.

NAME Milky Way.description: The path on which the journey led by Long Sash (001) took place, and encountered the various places and signs (002-005).

* alf Car.certainty: Uncertain identification, made based on the star's rising time.
Uncertain identification, made based on the star's rising time.

NAME Venus.description: As morning star. Represents a male divinity.

As evening star. Represents a female divinity whose hair falls over her face. In one story, the morning star continuously chases the evening star in the sky, which links to the theme of a man trying to follow his dead wife.
